module.name: property_space
module.keywords: module, physical quantity, property, characteristic, space

purpose.p: This application module is concerned with the specification of the nature of a property in terms of the physical phenomenon that is observed or measured.

A set of values or magnitudes of a physical phenomenon is a property space. A particular value or magnitude of a physical phenonmenon is an independent property definition that is a member of the property space.

example.p: 400 degrees Kelvin is an independent property definition within the space of temperatures.

li.p: the identity of a property space;
the tensor order and symmetry of a property space;
li.example: Temperature is a scalar space. Stress is a symnmetric second order tensor space.
Elasticity is a symmetric fourth order tensor space.

note.p: An independent property definition is a class that an individual physical object can be a member of. The class indicates the nature of an observable or measurable aspect of the individual physical object.
The mass of 10 Kg is an independent property definition. The widget with serial number 1234 in its state at 10:30 on 1998-11-05 is a member of this class.

A property space is a class that an independent property definition can be a member of. The class indicates the nature of the physical phenomenon that is the criterion for the independent property definition.
Mass is a property space. The mass that is 10 Kg is a member of this property space.

li.note: An independent property definition, is within the scope of the Independent_property_definition application module.

def.p: set of all values or magnitudes for a physical phenomenon

note.p: An independent property definition is a class that a physical thing can be a member of. Whether or not a physical thing is a member of the class is determined by the result of an observation or measurement.

A property space is a class that an independent property definition can be a member of. Whether or not an independent property definition is a member of the class is determined by the nature of the physical phenomenon that is observed or measured.

def.note: The deprecated terms do not have the word 'space', which indicates that the set or space of all possible values rather than a particular value is intended. Hence a term, such as 'physical quantity', does not distinguish between 'temperature' - a space of possible values, and 'the temperature of 20 degrees Celsius' - a particular temperature value.

description.p: The Property_space UoF identifies a property space and specifies its tenor order and symmetry.
description.note: This UoF distinguishes between a scalar property space such as 'pressure', and a second order tensor property space such as 'stress'.
